title: 1051-C
statement: C. Vasya and Multisetstime limit per test1 secondmemory limit per test256 megabytesinputstandard inputoutputstandard outputVasya has a multiset $$$s$$$ consisting of $$$n$$$ integer numbers. Vasya calls some number $$$x$$$ nice if it appears in the multiset exactly once. For example, multiset $$$\\{1, 1, 2, 3, 3, 3, 4\\}$$$ contains nice numbers $$$2$$$ and $$$4$$$.Vasya wants to split multiset $$$s$$$ into two multisets $$$a$$$ and $$$b$$$(one of which may be empty)in such a way that the quantity of nice numbers in multiset $$$a$$$ would be the same as the quantity of nice numbers in multiset $$$b$$$ (the quantity of numbers to appear exactly once in multiset $$$a$$$ and the quantity of numbers to appear exactly once in multiset $$$b$$$).InputThe first line contains a single integer $$$n~(2 \\le n \\le 100)$$$.The second line contains $$$n$$$ integers $$$s_1, s_2, \\dots s_n~(1 \\le s_i \\le 100)$$$ â€” the multiset $$$s$$$.OutputIf there exists no split of $$$s$$$ to satisfy the given requirements, then print "NO" in the first line.Otherwise print "YES" in the first line.The second line should contain a string, consisting of $$$n$$$ characters. $$$i$$$-th character should be equal to 'A' if the $$$i$$$-th element of multiset $$$s$$$ goes to multiset $$$a$$$ and 'B' if if the $$$i$$$-th element of multiset $$$s$$$ goes to multiset $$$b$$$.Elements are numbered from $$$1$$$ to $$$n$$$ in the order they are given in the input.If there exist multiple solutions, then print any of them.ExamplesInput43 5 7 1OutputYESBABAInput33 5 1OutputNO

processed.result:
You are given a set of $n$ integers.  A number is considered "nice" if it appears only once in the set.  

Your task is to split the set into two subsets (let's call them set A and set B) such that both sets have the same number of "nice" numbers.

If it's possible to do this split, output "YES" followed by a string indicating which element goes into which set.  If it's not possible, output "NO".

You are given a list of numbers.  Some numbers appear multiple times, and some appear only once.  

You need to split the list into two smaller lists.  The goal is to have the same number of numbers that appear only once in each of the two smaller lists.

If this is possible, say "YES" and show one way to split the list. If it's not possible, say "NO".
